title: Monday, 5th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hi. Welcome to Markets Live.

BE11:03am

BE11:03am

Borough rooftops, as seen from the FT's sixth-floor canteen about an hour ago.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

And aside from that, we'll be business as usual here on ML.

BE11:04am

For the same reasons we business as usual a few weeks ago. As per here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-05-23/

BE11:05am

Thanks to Iz and Kadhim for keeping things ticking in my absence last week. (I was in Berlin, and not answering my phone or checking my email, so apologies that I'm a bit behind the curve today.)

11:05 am
undefined
BE11:05am

It seems that today's theme is "big stuff, small response".

BE11:05am

Starting with oil.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Which on my screen is up 0.2% currently. A barrel of Brent costs $50.06.

BE11:06am

That's a pretty mild response to the news that Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Egypt, and Bahrain have cut diplomatic ties with Qatar.

BE11:07am

And shut down all land, sea, air routes to Qatar from SA, UAE, Egypt and Bahrain.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Story here: https://www.ft.com...-a3f4-c742b9791d43

BE11:08am

Let me cut to EFG Hermes for some snap analysis of what this actually means.

BE11:08am

This could put pressure on Qatar's logistics in terms of supply of food and other products, raising the risk of potential inflationary pressure. In addition, lower visitors from these GCC countries into Qatar, especially UAE and Saudi Arabia will weigh negatively on the hospitality sector as well; in April 2017, c49% of the 295,134 visitors into Qatar came from the GCC. In contrast, Qataris make up only 1% of arrivals to the UAE. One last consideration for the UAE would be that Qatar provides some of the UAE's gas needs through the Dolphin pipeline, we are unclear as to whether or not this will be impacted.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

According to the European Commission's 2016 trade statistics, UAE is the 3rd largest source of imports for Qatar (9.2% of total imports), Saudi Arabia is the 6th largest (4.6%). On the exports side, UAE is the 6th largest partner for Qatar with 5.4% of total exports and Egypt is the 10th largest with 2.1% of the total. In terms, of total trade, only the UAE shows up in the Top 10 with 6.8% of the total. Qatar doesn't feature in the total Top 10 trade partners for any of the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Bahrain. Weak trade flow between these countries means that the impact on these economies will be limited, and it seems that the most meaningful relationship in economic terms is between UAE/Qatar. Also, such political tensions will likely lead to higher CDS rates in the gulf, but the silver lining could be oil trading higher in the short term (Brent up +1% at the time of writing).

BE11:09am

We reiterate our ratings on these markets (OW Egypt, UW Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Qatar). Looking ahead we see the political crisis as having a short-term negative impact on markets, especially Qatar, leading to rising volatility given that GCC equity market volatility has been calm recently (in line with global trends). Looking ahead, we see very few catalysts for the UAE and Qatari equity markets. Egypt on the other hand remains our top pick in terms of growth potential following the float, while in Saudi Arabia we see the MSCI country classification announcement on 20 June as the next catalyst.

BE11:10am

On the equities side there's nearly no response.

11:10 am
SIG PLC (SHI:LSE): Last: 149.90, down 1.8 (-1.19%), High: 153.00, Low: 149.80, Volume: 354.73k
Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 788.00, down 9.5 (-1.19%), High: 801.50, Low: 788.00, Volume: 311.74k
BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 669.00, down 1 (-0.15%), High: 672.00, Low: 668.19, Volume: 1.36m
11:10 am
Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 375.03, up 3.03 (+0.81%), High: 377.00, Low: 369.00, Volume: 1.15m
BE11:11am

Any others with significant Doha exposure? I can't think of any others.

BE11:13am

Stadium construction contractors, possibly. Though there's a lot to happen before 2022.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

As for the oilers ....

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 464.65, up 1.9 (+0.41%), High: 469.50, Low: 463.85, Volume: 6.73m
Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,137, up 1 (+0.05%), High: 2,156, Low: 2,135, Volume: 947.92k
11:13 am
Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 175.10, down 0.9 (-0.51%), High: 179.70, Low: 173.00, Volume: 2.50m
BE11:14am

And Petrofac has bigger problems, of course.

BE11:14am

Actually, on that .....

11:14 am
BE11:14am

(And sorry for straying subjects already ...)

BE11:15am

I think we've mentioned the broader picture to the bribery allegations it faces, and how the SFO can be seen as fighting for its life right now.

BE11:15am

That theme gets a few pars in this week's Private Eye.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Which I'll share via a tweet, as a means to employ fair-dealing copyright legislation, but please do buy Private Eye anyway.

BE11:16am

https://twitter.com/Gian_TCatt/status/871067943970492416

BE11:16am

As we've observed before, you really don't want to be on the wrong side of a regulator that's seeking to preserve itself by demonstrating beyond doubt its own efficacy.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:17am

Having done oil, we should get miners out of the way.

BE11:18am

Underperforming quite badly.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Which we can tie, in convenience rather than confidence, to a bunch of forecast cuts from HSBC.

BE11:19am

The HSBC oil team has cut its oil price forecasts by c10% (Link). Higher than expected inventories due to the strong recovery in US upstream activity, weaker US demand and de-stocking in other areas (ie from floating storage) have meant oil prices have remained subdued. Sizeable inventory declines in the coming months are still expected. Longer term, a combination of decline rates, sharply lower investments and an almost total hiatus of major project approvals leaves the outlook for conventional non-OPEC supply looking extremely weak.

BE11:19am

All of our valuations for the LSE listed companies (excluding the recently initiated FXPO) are cut by 4% on the assumption of the stronger GBP/USD conversion rate (1.30 vs 1.25 previously), which is used to convert USD-dominated cash flows to GBP. JSE equities are quoted in ZAR and hence unaffected by this conversion factor.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

BHP’s and GLEN’s TPs are cut by 9%, the former due to its oil exposure, the latter due to the removal of the embedded 5% value-adding deal-making premium given our concerns that a mega-deal may be on the horizon. We downgrade ANTO and KAZ to Reduce from Hold, reflecting recent share price moves, and upgrade KIO to Hold from Reduce on its share price weakness.

BE11:20am

"a mega-deal may be on the horizon" for Glencore?

BE11:21am

The note I have doesn't develop any on that idea, though it seems to refer to Bunge.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

And "mega" seems a bit strong for that. Reading the note, it's more of a wider valuation range for a specific proposal rather than an optimistic view of an undefined one.

BE11:23am

Meh.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 283.00, down 3.75 (-1.31%), High: 287.60, Low: 282.30, Volume: 10.36m
11:23 am
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 786.50, down 18.5 (-2.30%), High: 795.50, Low: 775.50, Volume: 787.73k
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 473.80, down 20.6 (-4.17%), High: 487.00, Low: 467.30, Volume: 1.16m
undefined
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Oh, and before moving on from miners ....

BE11:24am

Kommersant reporting that Renova might doa take-private on Petropavlovsk.

Petropavlovsk PLC (POG:LSE): Last: 8.04, up 0.0239 (+0.30%), High: 8.10, Low: 8.02, Volume: 112.60k
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Renovo has 22.3% of POG plus 6.88% of votes in convertible bonds

BE11:25am

And is, Kommer reports, seeking to bounce it into a merger with Zoloto Kamchatki.

BE11:26am

Possibly to be followed by mergers with Highland Gold and GV Gold.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

No statement, of course. From any side.

BE11:27am

That's apparently fine, of course, because LSE rules just don't apply to Russian companies.

BE11:27am

Which is great news as we welcome back Polyus: https://www.ft.com...-a4c0-92520231c2e5

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Time to re-establish those contacts with VTB Capital and/or the barmen at the Swissôtel Krasnye.

BE11:30am

@wayneJ: thanks! Typo. Renova not Renovo. Apologies if that confused any bots looking out for Manchester biotechs.

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:31am

Continuing with the theme of "big news, small reaction" .............

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 327.80, up 11.8 (+3.73%), High: 340.00, Low: 327.20, Volume: 2.37m
BE11:31am

Hooray! It's an international deal!

11:31 am
BE11:31am

The one we've been waiting half a decade for.

BE11:32am

The one that was rumoured to be two weeks away for most of 2015 and again for most of 2016.

BE11:32am

And to be fair, the rumours weren't far off!

11:32 am
BE11:32am

The customer declines to be named, as expected.

BE11:32am

The numbers are underwhelming, as expected.

BE11:33am

What wasn't expected was that the customer isn't buying the full service.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Monday, then. And a picture.

BE11:33am

Hm.

BE11:34am

The agreement gives the partner the right to request in the future the installation of automated mechanical handling equipment in centralised warehouses, powered by OSP technology, on terms to be separately agreed but within given parameters.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.

BE11:34am

So, proof of sorts that Ocado can licence its Smart Platform thing.

BE11:35am

Not so much that the billion or so it's burnt through getting mechanical arms to lift bales of toilet roll was money well spent.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Sellside-wise, no-one's really changed their mind because there are no numbers in the statement.

BE11:37am

There's guidance that it'll be accretive long term. But do I really need to remind you how useful Ocado long-term forecasts are?

BE11:39am

What the hell. Just for the lols.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

BE11:40am

Still. Let's keep consulting Goldman. They know this business after all.

BE11:41am

What does it all mean?
Ocado will be providing its full software platform for the retailer’s online operations from the retailer’s manually operated centralised warehouse. This is important because we believe this will significantly reduce the lead time and up front capital required for OSP partners (and Ocado), removing a key barrier to signing further partners in our opinion. It is also a far more scaleable model for Ocado.
On the other hand, this agreement does not yet involve Ocado’s automated warehouse technology.
The partner will pay an upfront fee to Ocado for access to OSP together with , ongoing fees that are based on volume of products sold online (note the difference with the Morrisons’ agreement at Erith, which is based on capacity - reflecting the lower up front capital and risk to either party). The agreement gives the partner the right to request in the future the installation of automated mechanical handling equipment in centralised warehouses, powered by OSP technology, on terms to be separately agreed, but within given parameters.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

It's good news that they're not buying the whole rig. K. W'evs.

BE11:42am

We do not expect consensus to make material changes to estimates following this release. However, this agreement does demonstrate demand for Ocado’s product beyond the UK and management’s capacity and willingness to adapt their offer to address customer concerns. While not a sale of their fully automated solution (yet), we believe this solution represents a much more accessible product to retailers, potentially opening up the global grocery market much sooner to Ocado as it could

BE11:42am

.... allow them to partner with Ocado earlier in their own online evolution. As noted, this type of deal also appears much more scalable and less capital intensive (though likely less profitable) than providing fully automated solutions.
It is the sum of the multiple partners Ocado expect to sign over the medium term that would likely provide upside risk to consensus earnings if realised and we believe this deal makes that a more realistic expectation.
While the stock has been strong YTD, +c.20% vs pan European Grocery +c.3% we believe this agreement is a step forward for the business, removing some of the doubts about Ocado’s OSP product, and the stock should react positively to this news.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

It's an impressive show of optimism.

BE11:44am

Morgan Stanley less so, though still positive.

BE11:44am

We see this weekend's partnership as an encouraging 'proof-of-concept' rather than necessarily the material overseas deal that would be transformative to Ocado's financials. The name of the retailer is not disclosed, and it could be that this first agreement is relatively modest in its initial form. However, the signal sent for the future of Ocado's OSP business is encouraging on two fronts: 1) it proves there is appetite for Ocado's flexible and "all under one-roof" solution with the retailer opting first for the manual picking technology (easier to set-up, less capital intensive) before potentially moving towards a more automated & efficient fulfilment equipment; and (2) it suggests that incumbents continue to believe in centralised fulfilment of online grocery
orders (in this case, the fulfilment is mostly manual to start with, but we would argue the next logical step is to move to an automated fulfilment as soon as
scale permits). With Ocado reiterating clearly that its discussions with other
retailers across the globe are ongoing and today's positive signal sent to other retailers potentially considering an agreement with Ocado, we have higher
confidence in Ocado's ability to leverage its technology abroad. We continue to include 70p for international deals in our 420p price target, and remain buyers of the shares. As of Friday's close price, Ocado shares trade on ~17.1x 2018e
EV/EBITDA, which compares to a long-term 12m forward EV/EBITDA multiple of ~21x.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Bernstein, not so impressed.

BE11:45am

Is Ocado licensing some technologies like website order management and van routing? Software deals are competitive and warrant a few million £ of fees. Or is this a "full monty" deal like that with Morrisons, where Ocado runs sophisticated automated warehouse, earning tens of millions of EBITDA? The company insists it provides the 'entire suite of options', but the customer may not use certain parts of the platform.

BE11:45am

Ocado trades at 21X next year's EBITDA, three times higher than the industry's 6.6X EV/EBITDA. That means Ocado needs lots of big deals to warrant this valuation. In our view it needs about one Morrisons-sized deal every year for the first few years. Morrisons provides Ocado with 28.6 million EBITDA , out of Ocado's 93.6 million EBITDA (estimates 2017FY). The earnings potential of this and possibly similar deals is unclear to us therefore whether that warrants Amazon-style valuations.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

First indications suggest impact on EBITDA will be minimal and financial impact of this deal is nowhere near the size and scope of Morrisons. At 21X 2018 EV/EBITDA the shares price a much bigger deal than this. We remain Underperform with a price target of £1.90.

BE11:46am

Shares down to a 1.3% gain live. Was up 6% at the open. Will be unsurprised to see them finish negative.

undefined
11:47 am
BE11:47am

(@PaperChase: I missed that. Got a link?)

BE11:47am

Speaking of comedy stocks .....

Genel Energy PLC (GENL:LSE): Last: 94.77, down 3.98 (-4.03%), High: 102.50, Low: 92.00, Volume: 1.16m
11:48 am
BE11:48am

It's lost another two!

BE11:48am

Directors, that is.

BE11:48am

Nat, the co-founder, resigns. Along with Simon Lockett, a fellow NED.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

That's five directors gone since late April.

BE11:49am

Tony having started the exodus. He's due to quit at the June 6 AGM.

BE11:50am

Three days later Chakib Sbiti, then CFO Ben Monaghan. It's quite a turnover.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

How to read it? Dunno. RBC thinks it might not be bad news.

BE11:51am

Genel endured a share price collapse that was instigated by poor international drilling results, the oil price collapse and the insurgency in Iraq, and subsequently compounded by a series of reserve downgrades at its flagship Taq Taq oil field. During this period the company’s management team contracted – after Tuesday's AGM all but one of Genel's founders or their representatives – will have left. ‎

BE11:51am

With Stephen Whyte scheduled to start as Chairman on Tuesday, we expect him to be asked about a new direction for the business, the influence of new shareholders and‎ the make-up of the new board. ‎

11:51 am
BE11:51am

We believe that the company needs to persuade investors that its future lies in the exploitation of the Miran and Bina Bawi gas fields, which hold 11Tcf of raw gas. Significantly, the business is gaining the support of regional investors, including the Turkish energy firm Bilgin (a 15% shareholder), which has had board representation since March 2017, and Azeri conglomerate Daax Corp (12%). Given this support and an improving outlook for Kurdistan the stock has rallied recently to ~100p.

BE11:52am

(Ignore that raw disclaimer. Raw gas is not market chatter.)

BE11:52am

On Friday, we said we expected the new team to road-show a gas development-led, farm-out deal that provides a third-party endorsement, a mark-to-market (on an EV/boe basis there appears to be little or no value in the share price for Genel's gas resources) and leads subsequently to a refinancing (bonds mature in H1/19).‎
Our view: Today's news suggests that more substantial changes are afoot, as the ties with the past are broken. Shareholders will be hoping that the Genel reboot is accelerating; however, we would caution that the departure of major shareholder Nat Rothschild suggestions to us that the company's new direction could include some dilution of existing shareholders, perhaps as a result of a deal – merger or acquisition – rather than an equity refinancing.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Canaccord is a bit less willing to take a punt on mystery meat.

BE11:53am

Although some of these announcements caused no surprise or concern on their own, the quick-fire catalogue of senior management and board member exits taken together add up to a concerning view of the upper levels of the company's management and board. In our view, this creates considerable uncertainty just ahead of the AGM, particularly related to the two resignations announced today. Naturally we can't speculate on the underlying reasons for these changes, but our view is that until there is greater clarity investors should be cautious.
The stock has recently exceeded our TP and that, together with our concerns over the board and management changes, leads us to reduce our rating to HOLD (from Speculative Buy) but we maintain our TP of 95p/share (NPV15 core producing and risked valuation).

undefined
11:54 am
BE11:55am

Comptoir warning mentioned on the right.

Comptoir Group PLC (COM:LSE): Last: 23.00, down 8.5 (-26.98%), High: 23.00, Low: 23.00, Volume: 12.33k
BE11:55am

The Directors confirm that, overall, the past two months have seen a continuation of the difficult trading it reported at the time of its prelims in April 2017. While the business saw improved sales figures over the Easter weekend and half term holidays, unfortunately much of this benefit was subsequently lost in the final two weeks of the month. In May 2017 the Company also experienced an unexpected decline in like for like sales and profit at certain mature restaurants, particularly in retail-led locations and at its higher-spend restaurants, Levant and Kenza.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

I haven't been to Levant in years. It lost its purpose with the smoking ban.

BE11:56am

In addition, although the group as a whole is seeing a progression in sales, a number of the restaurants opened in 2016 remain behind expectations in terms of their anticipated maturity trading curve.

Like many of its peers in the sector, the Company is experiencing upward pressure on costs, including incremental wage costs and related taxes (apprenticeship levy), higher food and drink costs (driven by depreciation in sterling versus the Euro) and increases in rent and business rates. Together with the softening in consumer spending, these factors have had a significant impact on restaurant profitability and visibility over short-term trading trends. The Company has taken steps to limit the increase in central overheads

BE11:57am

A reminder that this thing floated at 50p.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

On a prospectus that's well worth reading for anyone interested in the food trade.

BE12:01pm

There are a number of interesting quirks about Comptoir, such as its use of a centralised kitchen (in, I think, Park Royal) and its use of licences where cooking isn't really permitted beyond warming stuff up.

BE12:01pm

Have a read here: http://investors.c...dia/c112118CCL.pdf

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Oh, look at the time. Sorry for being a tad slow today. First day back's never easy.

BE12:02pm

Haven't mentioned Sage, which is getting hit on a Numis downgrade.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Or possibly some residual disappointment about the payments disposal, or maybe even both.

BE12:03pm

Here's the gist of the Numis note.

BE12:03pm

Sage has disposed of US payments business, representing 7% (£36m) of FY17E EBITA, for 2.5% (£202m) of its EV, to GTCR, a US private equity fund. We are surprised a) at the low price (9x earnings), and b) that the disposal was not to an industry player able to fulfil Sage's ambition of partnering to provide a global payments platform to its customers. Management has previously indicated a desire to reinvest the proceeds into M&A, which might temper the dilution somewhat, although we doubt Sage will be purchasing anywhere close to the 9x PE multiple on the disposal. Little change to target price, reflecting 7% lower earnings but 5% higher multiple given the ongoing strong performance of the stock market. 21x CY18 EV:NOPAT not hugely demanding but we worry about capital allocation.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Sage management talk a strong story in terms of accelerating organic growth (to at least high single digit) and expanding margins; such an organic performance would, in our view, make Sage an exceptionally rare beast in the FTSE-100, meriting a materially higher multiple. Coupled with expanding earnings, that could drive a 60-100% share price increase, which leaves us surprised that management is not using the proceeds of this disposal to reduce the equity base. Gearing up (to 2.5x net debt:EBITDA) and shrinking the equity base by c. £1bn/13% could more than offset the disposal dilution.
Valuation. The shares have performed strongly (as has the market) in recent weeks; moving our target multiple up to 21x CY18 EV:NOPAT (was 20) and allowing a 20% chance that Sage delivers a 32% margin and is thus valued at 25x, we derive a 756p TP (was 765p) and move to Hold.

Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 709.64, down 19.36 (-2.66%), High: 723.00, Low: 708.50, Volume: 1.36m
undefined
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Ah! I've found the bit of the Comptoir prospectus I was looking for,

BE12:06pm

The Group is also able, by utilising its Central Production Unit, to operate its Comptoir Libanais brand from Class A3 commercial premises, which allow a ‘‘food and drink’’ business use, and Class A1 commercial premises, which allow a ‘‘shops and retail outlets’’ business use. The Directors believe that flexibility on future premises and the planning permission attached to these
premises gives the Group a competitive advantage against other restaurant operators when competing for new sites. The Directors believe that a majority of competitor branded restaurant concepts can only operate on premises with a Class A3 commercial use. The Directors believe that the Group has a motivated and dedicated team of personnel ensuring high standards across all divisions from culinary, operations, training, learning and development, to human resources, recruitment and marketing.

BE12:06pm

Page 12.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Now, the law on Class A3 premises is far from simple.

BE12:07pm

The inspectors have to come around and approve your setup. For small operators it takes ages, and sticking in an extractor fan can put you on the wrong side of the legislation.

BE12:09pm

It struck me at the time of flotation that Comptoir's was perhaps being a bit gung-ho to sell its reliance on A3 as a competitive cost saving rather than a risk factor.

12:09 pm
BE12:10pm

Anyway, the ROTR's in pun mode so I'm going to close for everyone's benefit.

BE12:10pm

Thanks for joining.

BE12:10pm

See you tomorrow.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:33am

"with orders initially fulfilled from their manually operated centralised warehouse." ..........
